questions.text: Which of the following is not a hypoproliferative anemia?
questions.solution:
Hemolytic anemia is not a hypoproliferative anemia.

Anemia can be defined as hemoglobin of < 13 g/dl in men and < 12 g/dl in women. Based on the mechanism of reduction of hemoglobin, anemia can be classified as:

  • Hypoproliferative anemias - due to impaired production of RBCs 
  • Hemolytic anemias and hemoglobinopathies - due to increased destruction of RBCs
  • Anemia due to blood loss

Hypoproliferative anemias are characterized by an abnormally low reticulocyte response (reticulocyte index <2–2.5) to reduced RBC production. They include:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Anemia of chronic disease (inflammation, renal disease, or malignancies)
  • Thalassemia
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Megaloblastic macrocytic anemias (folate and vitamin B12 deficiency)
  • Non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemias (alcohol use)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman came to the OPD one year after the birth of her last child. She had been treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. On examination, she is pale and investigations show a Hb of 5g/dl and a reticulocyte count of 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count? (Take normal Hb as 15g/dl)
questions.solution:
The corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) of this patient is 3.

CRC = Reticulocyte %  x  (Actual Hb / Normal Hb)

Plugging in the values given in the question,
CRC = 9% x 5/15 = 3%
Alternatively, CRC can be calculated using hematocrit (PCV) as follows:
CRC = Reticulocyte %  x  (Actual PCV / Normal PCV)

For these calculations, take normal Hb as 15g/dL and normal PCV as 45%.

The patient's hemoglobin level (5 g/dL) is significantly lower than the normal hemoglobin level (15 g/dL). To obtain an accurate assessment of reticulocyte production relative to the reduced number of circulating red blood cells, a correction factor has to be applied. CRC accounts for the anemia and provides a more precise estimate of the reticulocyte count.

When polychromatophilic macrocytes (prematurely released reticulocytes/shift cells) are observed in the peripheral blood smear, a second correction is applied to account for the longer life of reticulocytes to yield reticulocyte production index (RPI). 

In the classification of anemia, the patient's reticulocyte count is compared to the expected reticulocyte response. Reticulocytes can be identified by staining their ribosomal RNA with a supravital dye, resulting in the formation of blue or black punctate spots. They can be quantified manually or by using fluorescent dyes. The presence of reticulocytes indicates active red cell production.

The premature release of reticulocytes is typically associated with increased EPO stimulation. In hemolytic anemia, red cell production can increase six to seven times. If the RPI < 2 in a patient with anemia, a defect in erythroid marrow proliferation or maturation has to be suspected.

questions.text: What does the red cell distribution width deal with?
questions.solution:
Red cell distribution width (RDW) measures the range of red blood cell volumes and provides an assessment of their variability (anisocytosis).

The normal range of RDW is 11-14%. In the presence of uneven cell size (anisocytosis), the RDW increases to 15-18%.

RDW has clinical utility in two main scenarios:

  • In cases of microcytic anemia (low MCV), it helps differentiate between iron deficiency and thalassemia. Thalassemia is characterized by uniformly small red blood cells with a normal RDW, while iron deficiency leads to greater size variability and an increased RDW. 
  • A high RDW can indicate dimorphic anemia caused by chronic atrophic gastritis. Vitamin B12 malabsorption results in macrocytic anemia and blood loss leads to iron deficiency (microcytic anemia).

questions.text: Which of the following patients is unlikely to have the following finding on a peripheral smear study?

choices.text: A 55-year-old alcoholic man with ascites and jaundice
A 19-year-old girl who underwent emergency splenectomy after a road accident
A 25-year-old man with hemoglobin C disease
A 70-year-old woman undergoing dialysis for the past 3 years

questions.solution:
The black arrows in the given image denote target cells or codocytes. They are RBCs with a dense center (hyperchromic bull's eye) surrounded by an area of pallor. They are not a feature of renal disease (Patient D). 

Target cells are seen in the following conditions:

  • Thalassemia
  • Iron deficiency anemia
  • Liver disease
  • Post-splenectomy
  • Hemoglobin C disease
  • As artifacts in improperly prepared slides

questions.text: A first-year pathology resident prepares the following smear from a patient's blood sample. Which of the following is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The small, dense RBCs with absent central pallor seen in the given peripheral smear are called spherocytes. They appear due to decreased membrane surface area and are seen in the following conditions:

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Clostridial sepsis
  • Snake bites

questions.text: The following finding is not typically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows teardrop cells or dacrocytes. They are not seen in sideroblastic anemia.

Teardrop cells are seen in the following conditions:

  • Myelofibrosis
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Thalassemia
  • Severe iron deficiency

questions.text:
The following blood picture is seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
  1. Sickle cell disease
  2. Thalassemia
  3. Megaloblastic anemia
  4. Lead poisoning
  5. Dyshematopoiesis
questions.solution:
The given image shows Howell-Jolly bodies. They are remnants of RBC nuclei that occur in conditions with either defective production (dysplasia) or destruction of RBCs. They are observed in the following conditions:

  • Sickle cell disease (postsplenectomy)
  • Hyposplenism
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Dyshematopoesis
  • Hemolytic anemia

Thalassemia presents with microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, and target cells.

Lead poisoning presents with basophilic stippling or punctate basophilia on peripheral smears. These are RNA fragments seen as numerous basophilic granules dispersed in the cytoplasm of RBCs, as shown below.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a BMI of 41 kg/m2 is being evaluated for bariatric surgery. Which of the following procedures does not reduce the surface area for iron absorption?
questions.solution:
Iron absorption takes place in the duodenum. In sleeve gastrectomy, a portion of the stomach is resected but the duodenum remains intact. Hence, the surface area of iron absorption is not affected.

Dietary iron is efficiently absorbed in its heme form. Non-heme iron is less efficiently absorbed mainly because of interference by phosphates, tannins, oxalates, and other food constituents. Acidic pH enhances iron absorption by promoting the conversion of ferric to ferrous iron by the enzyme ferrireductase. 

 

The following are malabsorptive procedures that reduce the duodenal surface area and hence, reduce iron absorption:

  • Biliopancreatic diversion
  • Roux-en-Y gastric bypass
  • Duodenal switch

questions.text: You have prescribed oral iron supplements for an anemic young woman. Which of the following foods should she avoid taking along with these supplements?
questions.solution:
Tea contains tannins, which inhibit iron absorption. Hence, it should not be taken with iron supplements. Iron absorption is also reduced by:

  • Calcium supplements and antacids
  • Milk and dairy products
  • Proton pump inhibitors

Grapefruit and kiwi are acid-containing citrus fruits that create an acidic pH and hence, increase iron absorption. 

Broccoli contains ascorbic acid that also enhances iron absorption.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: The levels of which of the following will be detected first in a patient with iron deficiency?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of iron deficiency is a decrease in serum ferritin levels. This is called the state of negative iron balance.

Iron deficiency anemia develops in 3 stages:

  • Stage of negative iron balance - decrease in iron stores with normal serum iron and RBC morphology
  • Stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis - decrease in serum iron levels with normal RBC morphology
  • Stage of iron deficiency anemia - fall in hemoglobin with microcytic hypochromic RBCs

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the stage of negative iron balance in iron-deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
TIBC (total iron-binding capacity) does not decrease during the stage of a negative iron balance of iron deficiency anemia.

The progression to iron deficiency develops in 3 stages:

  • Stage of negative iron balance - Decrease in iron stores with normal serum iron and RBC morphology
  • Stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis - Decrease in serum iron levels with normal RBC morphology
  • Stage of iron deficiency anemia - Microcytic hypochromic RBCs
  Negative iron balance Iron-deficient erythropoiesis Iron deficiency anemia
Marrow iron stores Decreased Decreased Decreased
S. ferritin Decreased Decreased Decreased
TIBC Increased Increased Increased
S. Iron Normal Decreased Decreased
Transferrin saturation Normal Decreased Decreased
Red cell protoporphyrin Normal Increased Increased
Red cell morphology Normal Normal Microcytic hypochromic

questions.text: Patients with which of the following do not need to be evaluated for iron deficiency?

choices.text: Unusual craving to eat clay and paper
Insomnia due to a compulsive urge to keep moving the legs
Incidental finding of esophageal webs on upper GI endoscopy
Tingling and numbness of lower extremities

questions.solution:
Tingling and numbness of the lower extremities are suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. It is a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency, not iron deficiency. 

Iron-deficiency anemia is associated with the following findings:

  • Smooth tongue - due to loss of papillae
  • Cheilosis - fissuring at corners of mouth
  • Brittle nails
  • Koilonychia - spooning of nails
  • Pica - craving for non-edible foods like ice chips, hair, paper, clay
  • Plummer–Vinson syndrome - dysphagia due to the formation of esophageal webs 
  • Restless legs syndrome - compulsive urge to keep moving the legs which results in insomnia

questions.text: Which of the following PBF findings is least likely to be seen in patients with iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Image 4 shows dense RBCs with loss of central pallor or spherocytes. They are seen in autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and hereditary spherocytosis, not iron deficiency anemia.

 

The peripheral blood smear in iron deficiency anemia shows:

  • Microcytic hypochromic cells
  • Target cells
  • Pencil-shaped or cigar-shaped cells
  • Poikilocytosis- variations in the shape of RBCs
  • Anisocytosis- variations in the size of RBCs.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the ER after she faints at home. Her husband says that she is very body-conscious and does intermittent fasting. She has been on a vegan diet for the past 2 months. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 6 g/dL

MCV - 67 fL

MCH - 24 pg

RDW - elevated

TIBC - high

Peripheral smear - target cells noted
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia due to the following findings: 

  • Low MCV (N: 87-96 fL) 
  • Low MCH (N: 27-33 pg)
  • Elevated RDW 
  • High TIBC

Option A: Anemia of chronic disease is associated with low TIBC.

Options B and D: Anemia due to B12 and folate deficiency presents with a high MCV (macrocytosis).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is found to have a Hb of 7.2 g/dl and high ferritin levels. She has been undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer since last year. Which of the following is responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease. The chief mediator of this condition is hepcidin.

Anemia of chronic disease is associated with chronic inflammatory states such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, and malignancies. 

Hepcidin is a positive acute-phase reactant (ARP) that increases in chronic inflammatory states. It binds with ferroportin which results in both reduced iron intake in the gut and reduced iron transfer from macrophages to erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. Hence, hepcidin is a negative regulator of iron balance.

questions.text: Normocytic normochromic anemia is seen in patients with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Normocytic normochromic anemia is seen in chronic kidney disease (CKD).

It is also seen in the following conditions:

  • RBC membrane disorders - hereditary spherocytosis, elliptocytosis
  • RBC enzyme disorders - G6PD deficiency, Pyruvate kinase deficiency
  • Parvovirus B19 infection
  • Anemia of chronic disease - can also present as microcytic anemia

questions.text:

Hb - 7 gm/dL

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis  is found to have a hemoglobin of 6.3 mg/dl. Which of the following will be additionally seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Anemia of CKD is a form of hypoproliferative anemia presenting with decreased reticulocytes.

It mainly occurs due to a failure of erythropoietin production by the diseased kidney and a reduction in the survival of RBCs. Also, patients with CKD maintained on chronic hemodialysis may develop iron deficiency from blood loss through the dialysis procedure.

The following features are seen:

  • Normocytic and normochromic RBCs
  • Decreased reticulocytes
  • Serum iron, transferrin saturation, TIBC are usually normal or low
  • Decreased serum ferritin

The degree of anemia usually correlates with the severity of the renal failure. 

Note: Anaemia in CKD is not the same as anaemia of chronic disease.

questions.text: What is the predominant inheritance pattern of sideroblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Inherited forms of sideroblastic anemia are usually X-linked. Rarely, autosomal recessive forms may also occur.

X-linked sideroblastic anemia results from the deficient activity of the erythroid form of ALA-synthase (ALA-synthase 2) and is associated with ineffective erythropoiesis

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
High serum iron levels are seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia.

Sideroblastic anemia presents with the following features:

  • Serum iron level - high/normal
  • Transferrin saturation - high
  • Serum ferritin levels - high
  • TIBC - low/normal
  • Peripheral smear - dimorphic population (both microcytes and macrocytes).
  • Bone marrow study - marked erythroid hyperplasia.

The iron profile of sideroblastic anemia is opposite to that of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: The bone marrow biopsy sample of a patient with chronic anemia is stained with Prussian blue, as shown below. The stained deposits are present in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given image shows ringed sideroblasts, which are erythroid precursors in the marrow. In these cells, iron deposits in the mitochondria form a ring around the nucleus and are stained by Prussian blue.

The mature red blood cell counterparts of ringed sideroblasts in the circulation are called siderocytes. These cells have iron-containing basophilic granules called Pappenheimer bodies, as shown below.

Ringed sideroblasts and Pappenheimer bodies are pathognomonic of sideroblastic anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to cause sideroblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Chloramphenicol is known to cause sideroblastic anemia.

The agents known to cause sideroblastic anemia are:

  • Isoniazid
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Linezolid
  • Excessive alcohol
